  • Easy onion bhajis

Easy onion bhajis

  • Lulu Grimes
Makes 12
Easy
Prep: 30 mins
Cook: 20 mins
A star rating of 4.3 out of 5.110 ratingsRate
53 comments

Serve your crispy onion bhajis with cooling cucumber and mint raita as a snack, or eat alongside a homemade Indian curry. You'll be surprised by how easy they are to make

Egg-free
Gluten-free
Nut-free
Vegetarian
Try our app

These vegetarian samosas are a great way to get 3 of the 5-day into your family. They're also rich in fibre, folate, vitamin C, calcium and iron

Spicy vegetable chapati wraps
A star rating of 4.4 out of 5.58 ratings

A delicious and healthy vegetarian low-fat alternative to a curry, which can be deceivingly high in fat

Pea pakora pockets
A star rating of 3.8 out of 5.18 ratings

Cheap and easy to prepare, but fun for everyone to put together - the yogurt dressing really makes these

  • 2 onions
    finely sliced
  • 100g gram flour
  • ½ tsp gluten-free baking powder
  • ½ tsp chilli powder
  • ½ tsp turmeric
  • 1 green chilli
    deseeded and very finely chopped
  • vegetable oil
    for frying

For the raita

  • ½ cucumber
  • 150g tub Greek-style yogurt
  • 2 tbsp chopped mint

Nutrition: per serving

  • kcal86
  • fat5g
  • saturates1g
  • carbs7g
  • sugars2g
    low
  • fibre1g
  • protein3g
  • salt0.3g
    low
Ad
Report Ad

Method

  • step 1

    Soak the onion in cold water while you make the base mix. Sift the flour and baking powder into a bowl, then add the chilli powder, turmeric, chopped chilli and a good sprinkling of salt. Mix in about 100ml of cold water to make a thick batter – add a splash more if it feels too stiff.

  • step 2

    For the raita, peel the cucumber and grate it into a sieve set over another bowl. Mix the remaining ingredients with some seasoning and the drained cucumber – squeezing out any extra moisture with your hands – then spoon into a small serving bowl.

  • step 3

    Drain the onion well and mix it into the batter. Heat about 5cm of oil in a wok or deep pan. Do not fill the pan more than a third full. Add a tiny speck of batter. If it rises to the surface surrounded by bubbles and starts to brown, then the oil is hot enough for frying.

  • step 4

    Lower heaped tbsps of the bhaji mixture into the pan, a few at a time, and cook for a few mins, turning once, until they are evenly browned and crisp, so about 3-4 mins. Drain on kitchen paper, sprinkle with a little salt and keep warm while you cook the rest. Serve with the raita.

angelagorton27653

2 months ago
question

If you don’t have gram flour what can be used in it’s place

bindi1497
4 weeks ago

Plain flour, any flour really if wheat is not a problem, chickpea four, buckwheat. Don't use self raising though.

fran_wright2003CSNDuUQY

3 months ago

Having looked at many recipes I'm kot sure about this one. I always went to the Food Food recipes but think I will not be so lazy in future. There does not seem any justification to soak onions in water? This is why I researched further. If you cut onions and sprinkle salt this will draw out natural…

Joanneredgrove@icloud.com

7 months ago
question

Can you make these in advance? I think the recipe looks fab & I think you just season to your palate.

tpryse87780

11 months ago

Slice onions very thinly

JoePublic

1 year ago

Evening! Well I decided to give this recipe a go, with a couple of changes and was very pleasantly suprised! I used 1 onion (didn't soak them), then added a handful of finely chopped greens (cheap and nutrious), next I added 1/2 tsp of paprika, and 1/4 tsp of chilli powder with the other spices.…

3 months ago

Hi there. What flour did you use? I’m struggling to find Gram flour. Thanks
